title: STRIPE-seq library construction

source.description: Check RNA quality and concentration on an Agilent TapeStation using a High-Sensitivity RNA ScreenTape.

source.body: You should have at least 50 to 200 ng of total RNA at a concentration of at least 30 to 125 ng/μl. Your total RNA should also not be highly degraded, as measured by the quality of the rRNA peaks.

source.title: Terminator Exonuclease (TEX) Digestion of Uncapped RNA

source.description: Prepare TEX Reaction. TEX preferentially degrades uncapped RNA, thus reducing the amount of rRNA and degraded mRNA fragments in the sample.

source.body: TEX is magnesium-dependent, so ensure that the RNA storage buffer does not contain EDTA.

source.title: Terminator Exonuclease (TEX) Digestion of Uncapped RNA

source.description: Anneal reverse transcription oligo (RTO) to RNA. STRIPE-seq primes reverse transcription via a random pentamer adjacent to the full length TrueSeq R2 adapter (including the barcode) in the RTO.

Prepare one RTO annealing mix per sample in 0.2 mL PCR tubes.

Run final libraries on the Agilent TapeStation using a High Sensitivity D5000 ScreenTape.

source.body: Final libraries should be distributed between 250 to 750 bp with a total library amount of 25 to 100 ng.

source.title: Terminator Exonuclease (TEX) Digestion of Uncapped RNA

description: Accurate mapping of transcription start sites (TSSs) is key for understanding transcriptional regulation; however, current protocols for genome-wide TSS profiling are laborious and expensive. We present Survey of TRanscription Initiation at Promoter Elements with high-throughput sequencing (STRIPE-seq), a simple, rapid, and cost-effective protocol for sequencing capped RNA 5’ ends from as little as 50 ng total RNA. Including depletion of uncapped RNA and bead cleanups, a STRIPE-seq library can be constructed in approximately 5 hours.
